Literature Review: The spin Seebeck effect (SSE) has emerged as a powerful tool for probing various magnetic properties in solids since its discovery in 2008. This phenomenon, which involves the generation of a spin current due to a temperature gradient in magnetic materials, has attracted significant attention in the field of spintronics. The SSE has been observed in a wide range of magnetic systems, including ferromagnets, ferrimagnets, antiferromagnets, and even paramagnets, demonstrating its versatility as a probe for magnetic properties.One of the key aspects of the SSE is its sensitivity to elementary excitations in magnetic materials. Uchida et al. (2010) first demonstrated the SSE in a ferromagnetic insulator, yttrium iron garnet (YIG), revealing the role of magnons in the spin current generation. This discovery opened up new possibilities for studying magnon dynamics and transport in magnetic insulators. Subsequently, Rezende et al. (2014) developed a microscopic theory of the SSE based on magnon transport, providing a framework for understanding the phenomenon in ferromagnetic systems.The SSE has also proven to be a valuable tool for investigating spin correlations in magnetic materials. Hirobe et al. (2017) observed the SSE in the antiferromagnetic insulator Cr2O3, demonstrating that the effect is not limited to ferromagnetic systems. This study highlighted the potential of the SSE for probing spin dynamics in antiferromagnets, which are of increasing interest for spintronic applications due to their lack of stray fields and fast dynamics.In recent years, the SSE has been extended to more exotic magnetic systems, such as quantum spin liquids. Wu et al. (2015) reported the observation of the SSE in the quantum spin ice candidate Yb2Ti2O7, suggesting that the effect could be used to study quantum spin fluctuations in frustrated magnets. This work opened up new avenues for investigating quantum magnetism using thermal gradients.The sensitivity of the SSE to magnetic order and domain structures has been demonstrated in various studies. Aqeel et al. (2016) investigated the SSE in the helimagnetic insulator Cu2OSeO3, showing that the effect is strongly influenced by the magnetic field-induced transitions between different magnetic phases. This study highlighted the potential of the SSE as a probe for complex magnetic orders and phase transitions.Transport properties in magnetic materials can also be studied using the SSE. Cornelissen et al. (2015) used the SSE to investigate magnon transport in YIG over macroscopic distances, demonstrating the long-range nature of magnon spin currents. This work has important implications for the development of magnon-based devices for information processing and storage.The SSE has also been observed in paramagnetic systems, further expanding its applicability. Wu et al. (2016) reported the SSE in the paramagnetic insulator gadolinium gallium garnet (GGG), showing that the effect can be used to study paramagnetic spin fluctuations. This discovery opened up new possibilities for investigating spin dynamics in materials without long-range magnetic order.Recent advances in the field have led to the discovery of the nuclear spin Seebeck effect (NSSE). Shiomi and Saitoh (2019) observed the NSSE in GaAs, demonstrating that nuclear spins can also contribute to the thermal generation of spin currents. This finding extends the applicability of the SSE to the realm of nuclear magnetism, potentially providing a new tool for studying nuclear spin dynamics in solids.The SSE has also found applications in the emerging field of antiferromagnetic spintronics. Seki et al. (2015) demonstrated the SSE in the antiferromagnetic insulator MnF2, showing that antiferromagnets can be efficient sources of thermally driven spin currents. This work has important implications for the development of antiferromagnetic spintronic devices, which offer potential advantages in terms of speed and stability compared to their ferromagnetic counterparts.In conclusion, the spin Seebeck effect has proven to be a versatile and powerful probe for investigating a wide range of magnetic properties in solids. From elementary excitations and spin correlations to magnetic order and domain structures, the SSE provides valuable insights into the fundamental physics of magnetic materials. As research in this field continues to advance, it is likely that the SSE will find even more applications in the study of complex magnetic systems and the development of novel spintronic devices.
